column4: Baidu says reports of IPO for video-streaming site iQiyi.com are inaccurate
column5: BEIJING Chinese internet giant Baidu Inc said on Friday that reports it is currently pushing for an initial public offering for its video-streaming site iQiyi.com are inaccurate.

column2: Barclays Inverse US Treasury Composite ETN
column4: U.S. sues Barclays  ex-executives for mortgage securities fraud
column5: NEW YORK The U.S. Department of Justice on Thursday sued Barclays Plc  and two former executives on civil charges of fraud in the sale of mortgage-backed securities during the run-up to the 2008-09 financial crisis.

column4: FDA approves Biogen drug for lead genetic cause of infant death
column5: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration on Friday said it has  approved Biogen Inc's drug to treat spinal muscular atrophy  the leading genetic cause of death in infants.

column4: Caesars unit resolves lender dispute  eyes bankruptcy exit
column5: CHICAGO Caesars Entertainment Corp's  bankrupt operating unit resolved a dispute with its lenders on Friday  paving the way for a consensual plan to push the casino group out of its $18 billion Chapter 11.

column4: Ericsson  Cisco to target corporate  public sector clients in 2017
column5: STOCKHOLM Global telecoms equipment gear maker Ericsson  plans to expand its partnership with Cisco Systems Inc  by serving new corporate clients and the public sector in 2017  its North American chief told Reuters in an interview.

column4: Ericsson  Cisco to target corporate  public sector clients in 2017
column5: STOCKHOLM Global telecoms equipment gear maker Ericsson  plans to expand its partnership with Cisco Systems Inc  by serving new corporate clients and the public sector in 2017  its North American chief told Reuters in an interview.

column4: Icahn regulatory role gives activist investors strong Washington voice
column5: NEW YORK/WASHINGTON/BOSTON U.S. chief executives  already wrestling with a steady flow of activist investors in their board rooms  face a newly challenging landscape now that the loudest voice of the bunch will have the ear of the next president and his securities' rule makers.

column4: U.S. sues Barclays  ex-executives for mortgage securities fraud
column5: NEW YORK The U.S. Department of Justice on Thursday sued Barclays Plc  and two former executives on civil charges of fraud in the sale of mortgage-backed securities during the run-up to the 2008-09 financial crisis.

column4: Trump pressures Lockheed  says told Boeing to price out fighter aircraft
column5: HONOLULU/LOS ANGELES U.S. President-elect Donald Trump heaped pressure on Lockheed Martin Corp on Thursday  saying he viewed costs for the aerospace company's F-35 fighter as too high and had asked Boeing Co to offer a price for an older aircraft that lacks the same stealth capabilities.

column4: Bonanza Creek  other U.S. energy firms announce Chapter 11 plans
column5: Bonanza Creek Energy Inc  and two other energy firms announced on Friday plans to file for bankruptcy in coming weeks  joining a long list of U.S. energy companies that have succumbed to a drop in oil prices.

column4: Azerbaijan extends BP's deal for giant oilfields until 2050
column5: Oil major BP has agreed with Azerbaijan to extend a contract to develop the country's biggest fields by a quarter of a century to 2050 in a move to unlock billions of dollars of fresh investments in the Caspian Sea deposits.

column4: Azerbaijan extends BP's deal for giant oilfields until 2050
column5: Oil major BP has agreed with Azerbaijan to extend a contract to develop the country's biggest fields by a quarter of a century to 2050 in a move to unlock billions of dollars of fresh investments in the Caspian Sea deposits.

column4: Cardinal settles with U.S. over painkiller shipments to pharmacies
column5: NEW YORK A drug distributor owned by Cardinal Health Inc has agreed to pay $10 million to resolve claims it failed to alert the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration to suspiciously large orders of addictive painkillers by New York-area pharmacies.

column4: Indonesia  Philippine groups acquire Chevron's $3 billion geothermal assets
column5: MANILA Philippine property to banking conglomerate Ayala Corp  said on Friday two groups of companies in which its energy unit has stakes will acquire Chevron's  geothermal assets in Indonesia and the Philippines  earlier valued at $3 billion.

column4: U.S. hits Credit Suisse  Deutsche Bank with toxic debt penalties
column5: ZURICH/FRANKFURT Credit Suisse  and Deutsche Bank  have been hit with a combined penalty of more than $12 billion over the sale of U.S. toxic debt  further hampering two of Europe's leading investment banks as they struggle with weak earnings. | Video

column4: Global stocks steady  U.S. dollar near 14-year peak on low volumes
column5: NEW YORK Key stock indexes around the world were little changed on Friday  as were the U.S. dollar and U.S. Treasury yields  in low volume trading ahead of the Christmas holiday weekend.

column4: Deutsche wins biggest in U.S. regulatory casino
column5: LONDON (Reuters Breakingviews) - European lenders' end-of-year fines for mortgage mis-selling have confounded market expectations and left a clear winner: Deutsche Bank. Although Britain's Barclays failed to achieve similar closure  Germany's largest lender by assets and peer Credit Suisse's agreed settlements with the U.S. Department of Justice remove a major question mark.

column4: Credit Suisse agrees $5.3 billion U.S. mortgage settlement
column5: ZURICH Credit Suisse  had agreed in principle to pay U.S. authorities $2.48 billion to settle claims it misled investors in residential mortgage-backed securities it sold in the run-up to the 2008 financial crisis  the Swiss bank said on Friday.

column4: Deutsche Bank agrees to $7.2 billion mortgage settlement with U.S.
column5: NEW YORK/FRANKFURT Deutsche Bank  has agreed to a $7.2 billion settlement with the U.S. Department of Justice over its sale and pooling of toxic mortgage securities in the run-up to the 2008 financial crisis.

column4: Deutsche wins biggest in U.S. regulatory casino
column5: LONDON (Reuters Breakingviews) - European lenders' end-of-year fines for mortgage mis-selling have confounded market expectations and left a clear winner: Deutsche Bank. Although Britain's Barclays failed to achieve similar closure  Germany's largest lender by assets and peer Credit Suisse's agreed settlements with the U.S. Department of Justice remove a major question mark.

column4: How Deutsche's big bet on Wall Street turned toxic
column5: FRANKFURT Deutsche Bank's pursuit of success on Wall Street has come at a high price  a $7 billion plus penalty illustrating the extent of its decline since 2008 when its then chief executive claimed it was one of the "strongest banks in the world".

column4: German government welcomes Deutsche Bank settlement
column5: BERLIN The German government has welcomed Deutsche Bank's  $7.2 billion settlement with the U.S. authorities over the lender's sale and pooling of toxic mortgage securities  a Finance Ministry spokeswoman said on Friday.

column4: Blackstone in talks to buy stake in Energy Transfer assets
column5: Private-equity firm Blackstone Group LP is in talks to buy a stake in assets owned by Energy Transfer Partners LP  the company building the controversial Dakota Access pipeline  a source familiar with the situation said on Thursday.

column4: China fines GM venture $29 million for monopolistic pricing: state TV
column5: BEIJING China will fine U.S. automaker General Motors Co's  joint venture 201 million yuan ($29 million) for monopolistic pricing  state television reported on Friday  ending speculation after an official warned of penalties against a U.S. carmaker. | Video

column4: Blackstone in talks to buy stake in Energy Transfer assets
column5: Private-equity firm Blackstone Group LP is in talks to buy a stake in assets owned by Energy Transfer Partners LP  the company building the controversial Dakota Access pipeline  a source familiar with the situation said on Thursday.

column4: U.S. Justice Dept. orders whistleblower to testify in Wells Fargo probe
column5: The U.S. Department of Justice has subpoenaed a high-profile whistleblower in its criminal investigation into Wells Fargo & Co's  opening of accounts without customer permission.
